title: Geth v.1.13.4 - BAD BLOCK - Invalid merkle root - Error when I make a transaction
body:
#### System information

Geth version: `1.13.4`
OS & Version: Linux

#### Expected behaviour

The expected result is that transactions are distributed to other blocks without problems.

#### Actual behaviour

> I'm running my own **3 node PoA** private blockchain and trying to notarize on the blockchain some hashes. I moved forward with an old problem of mine, which I haven't been able to solve yet: #28154 

Every single node is on different Linux Machines with its own IP address.
I have tried every configuration and every test to resolve this **BAD BLOCK** error, but I still haven't been able to fix it.

I think I have understood the reason why the Geth system (in my specific case) returns this particular error.

Doing some tests, I noticed that if in Genesis I set only one address referring to a single node as a signatory and leave the aforementioned node active, the network works perfectly. Unfortunately, having only one active node is not the best scenario, so inevitably I created others.

The very strange thing is that as soon as the transaction that is signed by node1 is also distributed to node2 or node3, they receive the BAD BLOCK error with this message printed in the console:


I also noticed another very interesting thing. If I execute some transactions and mine some blocks ONLY with node 1 active (as previously said, this is how it works) and subsequently activate node 2, instead of synchronizing with the mined nodes, node 2 goes into BAD BLOCK as soon as the blocks "arrive" nodes mined by node1.

Besides this I noticed that if I run `admin.peers` on node2 before the nodes previously mined by node1 arrive, it still returns node1 and this makes me understand that initially a synchronization occurs, but when the nodes are read and it occurs this error, `admin.peers` becomes empty = []

If you need more information, just tell me.

Can someone help me?

I think it was more or less resolved by this comment in the earlier thread: 

> As far as I can tell, the node which generated this block (block 28) is corrupt. Perhaps you should do a disk-check and/or a RAM-check.

Check the RAM and the disk of that machine -- it has produced an erroneous block. If you are using the same machine now, it's not (very) surprising if it happens again (now on block 1)

Thank you for your input. After conducting numerous tests, I have pinpointed that the issue arises from nodes being hosted on separate machines under AWS EC2. Interestingly, when I ran the blockchain locally with nodes on the same machine, everything functioned as expected. However, replicating this setup on a distributed network under AWS results in synchronization problems.

This discrepancy indicates that the problem may not be related to the hardware integrity of the machine that generated block 28, as initially suggested. Instead, the challenges with synchronization seem to be tied to the distributed nature of our setup on AWS EC2.

Do you have any thoughts on this?

What do you mean "distributed network"? Are you referring to the distributed storage you used for setting up Geth node?

Honestly I have no idea what's the spec of `AWS EC2` and what type of storage it has. But normally deploying node on the AWS works for us.

I mean these AWS servers are in different zones. In any case, I don't think they are memory problems, the memory is all free, it has been cleaned, I have done a configuration of the Geth nodes from scratch several times. 
Yesterday I did another test: I tried to connect from local to the remote node on the AWS machine to see if they synchronized, but nothing, always BAD BLOCK.
I don't know what else to try anymore.

> Do you have any thoughts on this?

Honestly, makes zero sense to me. There's nothing special about aws ec2 backends.

Yes, so for linux, here is some info 
- https://superuser.com/questions/171195/how-to-check-the-health-of-a-hard-drive
- https://askubuntu.com/questions/59064/how-to-run-a-checkdisk

I'd try `badblocks`, `smartctl` and `fsck`. 

Mem checks might be more difficult (https://askubuntu.com/questions/343114/how-to-check-for-errors-in-ram-via-ubuntu), don't know if AWS allows you do to ram-tests during bootup, but otherwise perhaps you could try `memtester`?

Those are my suggestions.
